learning_outcomes.description: sketch, interpret and manipulate functions of two or more variables.
calculate the equations of tangent planes, and use them to approximate functions.
find the maxima and minima of functions of two variables.
apply the method of Lagrange multipliers to optimisation problems.
solve and analyse certain families of first and second order ODEs.
model a problem with ODEs and either analytically or numerically solve the differential equation and interpret the output.
work fluently with parametric forms of curves, and derive parametric forms.
understand fields and determine conservative fields and path integrals.
model and solve problems with some real-world complexity.

assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
You must attend your applied classes in-person. For each applied class (except Weeks 1, 4 and 11), you will complete an assessed group-based collaborative exercise containing problems similar to MATH1052 exam questions. Hand in the applied class exercise to your casual academic at the end of the Applied Class.

There are 10 assessed applied class exercises (all weeks except Weeks 1, 4 and 11). The best 8 will count for assessment.

If you are unwell then DO NOT attend your in-person applied class. Please attend a different applied class during the week.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The exercise is submitted to casual academics at the end of the applied class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description: You must submit detailed written solutions to a collection of mathematical problems. Each assignment is weighted 7.5%.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit via Gradescope. Instructions are on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
In-semester Saturday

28/03/2026 - 2/05/2026

The in-semester Saturday exam will be on one of the following dates:

  • Saturday 28 March 2026 (Week 5)
  • Saturday 18 April 2026 (Week 7)
  • Saturday 2 May 2026 (Week 9)

You will receive a personalised exam timetable with details of the date, time and venue of the in-semester exam.
assessments.task_description:
The in-semester examination is closed book and will be invigilated on-campus for all students.

The total time for the in-semester exam is 10 minutes (planning time) + 90 minutes (working time). 

The exam is closed-book. Calculators are not allowed. 

There will be a range of problem solving questions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The examination is closed book and will be invigilated on-campus for all students. The exam will be an in-person, paper-based exam. Students will sit the exam at the St Lucia Campus.

The total time for the end of semester exam is 10 minutes (planning time) + 120 minutes (working time). 

There will be a range of problem solving questions. 

Calculators are NOT allowed.

A formula sheet will be provided.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom O-week To Exam week 2(16 Feb - 21 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Independent work

During the semester students are expected to work on MATH1052 outside of class time to consolidate the information given during lectures, work on the problem sheets and assignments, complete extra practice problems and study for examinations.
learning_activities.topic_description: Independent work During the semester students are expected to work on MATH1052 outside of class time to consolidate the information given during lectures, work on the problem sheets and assignments, complete extra practice problems and study for examinations.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Applied Classes

Applied Classes will provide students an opportunity to practise problems and collaborate with peers.
learning_activities.topic_description: Applied Classes Applied Classes will provide students an opportunity to practise problems and collaborate with peers.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Lectures define the course material. They set out the basic theory and demonstrate techniques for problem solving. They cover all the core material required for the course. While attendng lectures, students are expected to annotate their course notes as the lecturer works through the notes, and complete the examples in the course notes. You have access to a UQExtend website which contains extra resources (pre-recorded videos, quizzes and interactive animations). The UQExtend site link is on Blackboard.
